conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 24 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<PROPOSALS COUNT> [add here (inclusive of current)] </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 24 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As my goal is to sell my resource for ZUP and it cost me 24 ZUP to produce, my initial proposal will be a bit higher than my production cost to start the negotiation process and to cover any potential bargaining that may occur. </reason>

<message> I'm offering one unit of X, which cost me 24 ZUP to produce. Considering its value and production cost, I'm starting the negotiation at 30 ZUP. Let's work together to find a fair trade. </message>

<other player message> I understand the cost to produce the object and its value, but I would like to propose a counteroffer of 26 ZUP. This would still give you a slight profit above the production cost, and it would be a more attractive deal for me. Let's find a balance that benefits us both. </other player message>

<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 26 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 2 </PROPOSALS COUNT>

<reason> The counteroffer from Player BLUE is above my production cost, which is good, but it is lower than my initial asking price. I would like to propose a price closer to my initial ask to try and maximize my profits while still making it a reasonable deal for Player BLUE. Splitting the difference could be an effective strategy here. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 28 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your counteroffer. I appreciate your willingness to negotiate. I would like to meet halfway between my initial offer and your counteroffer. How about we settle at 28 ZUP? This price still gives me a reasonable profit margin while respecting the value of the resource. </message>

<other player message> I'm glad we're making progress in our negotiation. I propose we go for 27 ZUP, splitting the difference from your last offer. This would be a fair compromise, giving you a profit while still being economical for me. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 27 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 3 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 24 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has made a reasonable counteroffer that is very close to my previous proposal. It offers me a profit of 3 ZUP above my production costs. It might be prudent to accept this offer, as further negotiation may not yield a significantly higher price and could risk the deal. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your proposal. I believe 27 ZUP is a fair compromise that benefits both of us. I accept your offer. Looking forward to future dealings with you. </message>
